wikipedia_page.main: Edward Samuel Morris (10 August 1940 – 29 May 2016) was a British art historian perhaps best known for his "masterly" French Art in Nineteenth Century Britain.

response: * Edward Morris (1940-2016), art historian, born in Bognor
* Edward Morris (businessman) (1866–1913), president of Morris & Company
* Edward Morris, 1st Baron Morris (1859–1935), lawyer and Prime Minister of Newfoundland

He was a Rome scholar at the British School at Rome, having won the Engraving Prize in 1925,Yorkshire Evening Post, 13 July 1925, "Latest News", p. 9. the same year that Edward Irvine Halliday (1902–1984), a fellow Liverpudlian and also a former student at the RCA, won the Painting Prize.See Compton, Ann: Edward Halliday: Art for Life, 1925-1939 (exh. cat. 24 October – 19 December 1997). Liverpool: University of Liverpool Art Gallery, , , p. 18. According to Edward Morris, writing in the Connoisseur, Wedgwood "reverted to architectural subjects; his line became harder and more precise; his effects clearer and sharper; less of his work was etched, more engraved; some of the credit for these effects must go to the printer, David Strang".See Connoisseur, vol. 180, no. 725, July 1972, p. 239. See William Strang's portrait of his son David on the William Strang page.

* Walker Art Gallery, Liverpool: "Geoffrey Heath Wedgwood", 2 February – 4 March 1972In his review of the exhibition Edward Morris wrote: "Wedgwood was one of the first pupils to be able to study engraving alone for his diploma [at the RCA] and he profited  from the vigorous manner of Job Nixon [1891–1938] rather than from the more refined, delicate approach of the Professor, Sir Frank Short." Connoisseur, vol. 180, no. 725, July 1972, p. 239.
